bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1941

div1.p: Andrus appreciates Hench's input concerning the manuscript Andrus wrote about his own experience as a volunteer in the yellow fever experiments. He discusses the manuscript, entitled “The Tale of a Guinea Pig.” and encloses a copy.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1941
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
2-23-41.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I am very conscious of the fact that you have devoted a lot
of your time going over my manuscript and in pointing out,
in considerable detail, how it might be improved. This,
with previous courtesies at your hands, places me under
heavy obligation to you.

Of course you are absolutely right in all your suggestions.
If I were writing this about someone other than myself, I
might be able to follow your formula with fair success.
With your humble servant in the dual roles of author and
hero, I'm afraid the author would murder the hero, or vice
versa, before the job could be completed.

General Kean - after reading a carbon of the same manuscript
you have - wrote, “I want to express my admiration for the
modesty, simplicity and accuracy with which you have told
your story”.

I made a very serious effort to re-write my epic along the
lines suggested by you but gave up in despair after starting
page five. Am enclosing carbons. Can you imagine
General Kean expressing admiration for the modesty of this?

Of course I may have missed the boat. What I have written
may not be at all what you had in mind. Is it?

Another thing: When I first started this I planned to ful-
fill these objectives:
1 - Tell what a dread plague yellow fever
USED TO BE.
2 - Explain WHY the Army too action.
3 - Give a condensed but accurate account
of the work of Major Reed's Board.
4 - Credit the Board for the results.
5 - Tell of my obscure role.

I thought then - and still think - that objective 5 would be
without point unless the remaining four objectives are cover-
ed understandably and it would be difficult to condense them
more than at present and preserve their narrative form.

In eliminating quoted matter, do you think the letter from
Major Reed to General Sternberg (page 2 as revised) should
be in some other form?
